S3.T3.footnotes: The column labeled “Sampling” specifies whether the analysis applies to the partial client participation scenario. When “no sampling” is indicated, it signifies that the analysis exclusively pertains to the scenario with full client participation, i.e., m=n𝑚𝑛m=n.The BG (Bounded Gradient) assumption refers to 1n​∑i=1n‖∇ufi​(u,vi)‖2≤b21𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑢subscript𝑓𝑖𝑢subscript𝑣𝑖2superscript𝑏2\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\|\nabla_{u}f_{i}(u,v_{i})\|^{2}\leq b^{2}, which is much stronger than the BGD Assumption 2.2.
references: by removing the influence of σv2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑣2\sigma_{v}^{2} from the rate. This result is superior to existing best-known convergence rates for FedAvg in the literature, see the upper part of Table 3 for detailed comparison.

without assuming any bounded gradient dissimilarity. This is a novel result since existing analyses for FedAvg rely on this restrictive assumption. The lower part of Table 3 lists several existing FedAvg convergence rates for problem (2). It is observed that our derived rate outperforms all baselines under the mildest assumptions.
